1620/A0/04/002/008.status_value: The Justice for Children Policy was recently approved by Cabinet. As part of the process for developing the policy  consultations with National House of Chiefs and Queen mothers indicated that community leaders are willing to support and handle mechanisms put in place for dealing with children's offending behaviors. Roles and responsibilities have been assigned to traditional authorities in the policy. Based on this  further engagement with the Ministry of Chieftaincy and Traditional will be dee
1620/A0/04/002/008.indicator_name: Districts with effective alternative dispute resolution mechanisms for dealing with children's criminal cases.
1620/A0/04/002/008.headline: Traditional authorities ¿ Chiefs and Queen mothers ¿ commence close collaboration with Police and social welfare in line with Policy expectations and the Police establishes child-friendly space in the Northern region.
1620/A0/04/002/008.baseline_value: Close to zero as per system mapping report of 2010

1620/A0/04/002/008.status_value: The new Justice for Children Policy are expected to provide the impetus for community preventive work in the areas of child justice based key priorities identified. Prevention is one of the cardinal principle of the policy. The Police demonstrated great commitment to the cause by intensifying its efforts to reach out to communities and schools  dialoguing about role of police and crime prevention. This was seen particularly in the North where some 11 districts documented visits from DOVVSU polic
1620/A0/04/002/008.indicator_name: Number of stakeholders (police and others) engaged in crime prevention at community  district  regional and national level targeting children and young people.
1620/A0/04/002/008.headline: Traditional authorities ¿ Chiefs and Queen mothers ¿ commence close collaboration with Police and social welfare in line with Policy expectations and the Police establishes child-friendly space in the Northern region.

1620/A0/04/002/008.status_value: The Justice for Children Policy clearly indicates that dealing effectively with juvenile delinquency involves two distinct but overlapping endeavors¿prevention and intervention¿each of which requires the efforts of both the formal justice actors as well as the informal actors. To this end  the Ministry of Chieftaincy and Traditional Affairs has engaged traditional authorities through the National House of Chiefs and Regional Houses of Chiefs in selected districts in a dialogue to advance underst
1620/A0/04/002/008.indicator_name: Guidelines for traditional authorities (Chiefs  Queen mothers) developed for handling children
1620/A0/04/002/008.headline: Traditional authorities ¿ Chiefs and Queen mothers ¿ commence close collaboration with Police and social welfare in line with Policy expectations and the Police establishes child-friendly space in the Northern region.

1620/A0/04/002/007.status_value: Monumental achievement has been made in integrating child friendly Policing into the Ghana police Service. Based on a gap analysis  an SOP for handling children has been developed and validated. A curriculum drafting has begun to integrate the SOP. Structured training for the entire police force will begin on finalization of the curriculum and development of training manuals.
1620/A0/04/002/007.indicator_name: Number of juvenile justice cases diverted at police and court level
1620/A0/04/002/007.headline: Ghana Police service starts to implement new SOPs on handling cases involving children and more insights are gained on how the judicial service could improve the experience for children in court.

1620/A0/04/002/007.status_value: Structured program for children in contact with the law is yet to happen. This is due to fact that the Justice for Children Policy has just been approved  structured program for reintegration will become part of the implementation of the policy by service providers. It is further anticipated that engagement with CSOs will also facilitate the program for reintegration of young offenders. As a first step  CSO representatives on the Advisory Committee contributed to the policy development process.
1620/A0/04/002/007.indicator_name: Proportion of young offenders benefitting from structured programmes for social reintegration and being offered legal aid.
1620/A0/04/002/007.headline: Ghana Police service starts to implement new SOPs on handling cases involving children and more insights are gained on how the judicial service could improve the experience for children in court.

1620/A0/04/002/007.status_value: 2015: The Justice for Children's Policy was recently approved by Cabinet. The Policy now provides the framework for putting in place a structured program for children in contact with the law. As a first even prior to the approval of the Policy  an SOP has been developed for the Ghana Police Service for handling children in contact with the law. A new curriculum for training all new recruits is being developed based on the SOP. Meanwhile  some of the training schools have begun training their rec

1620/A0/04/002/007.status_value: Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for handling children in conflict with the law and SOPs for handling cases involving child victims and witnesses were finalized on the basis of an iterative capacity and skills gap analysis  which was validated by the top hierarchy of the Police. The study into court is still on-going.
1620/A0/04/002/007.indicator_name: Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for Police finalized  service guidelines and court directives issued for justice services
1620/A0/04/002/007.headline: Ghana Police service starts to implement new SOPs on handling cases involving children and more insights are gained on how the judicial service could improve the experience for children in court.

1620/A0/04/002/007.status_value: Training resources on the content of the SOPs were developed and 40 individuals from Police training schools underwent master training to be able to teach the content of the SOPs. The first batch of new recruits of the GPS currently undertaking their training will be the first such group to be exposed to the content of the SOPs. From now on  child-friendly policing will be part of all police trainings.
